questions.text: A woman presents with dysuria and yellowish discharge. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria

 

The presence of gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain is a classic finding in infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is a sexually transmitted bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically presents with symptoms such as dysuria (painful urination) and a yellowish or purulent discharge, which aligns with the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Gram staining is a key diagnostic tool that helps differentiate bacterial species based on the characteristics of their cell walls. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus, meaning it appears as paired spherical bacteria that do not retain the crystal violet stain used in gram staining but do take up the counterstain, appearing pink or red under a microscope.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, which is a flagellated organism. While trichomoniasis can cause dysuria and yellowish discharge, it would not present with gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If the organism had flagella, Trichomoniasis would be a consideration, but the gram stain findings rule it out.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis is another sexually transmitted bacterium that can cause symptoms similar to those of gonorrhea. However, it does not appear as gram-negative diplococci on gram stain. Instead, it is typically detected by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT).

 

Option D. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is characterized by an imbalance in the vaginal flora and typically diagnosed using Amsel's criteria or by identifying clue cells on microscopy. It is not associated with gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of gram-negative diplococci in a patient with dysuria and yellowish discharge is highly indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, a common cause of gonorrhea

questions.text: Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) acts on which of the following Tyrosine Receptor Kinases? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. TRK B

 

Explanation: 

 

Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) specifically binds to and activates TRK B receptors. TRK B (tropomyosin receptor kinase B) is a transmembrane receptor with intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity. When BDNF binds to TRK B, it triggers autophosphorylation of the receptor, activating multiple signaling pathways including MAPK, PI3K, and PLCγ pathways. This activation plays crucial roles in neuronal survival, differentiation, and synaptic plasticity, particularly in long-term potentiation (LTP).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: TRK A serves as the high-affinity receptor for nerve growth factor (NGF), not BDNF. TRK A is primarily expressed in nociceptive neurons and sympathetic ganglia.
  • Option C: TRK C is the primary receptor for neurotrophin-3 (NT-3). It is predominantly expressed in proprioceptive neurons and plays important roles in sensory neuron development.
  • Option D: This is not a recognized member of the Trk receptor family. The mammalian Trk family consists only of TRK A, TRK B, and TRK C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BDNF specifically binds to TRK B receptors, initiating crucial signaling cascades that support neuronal survival, differentiation, and synaptic plasticity in the central nervous system.

choices.text: Family is not satisfied with police

questions.text: In which condition both police and magistrate can do the inquest, but magistrate inquest will be preferred? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Family is not satisfied with police

 

Explanation:

 

An inquest is a legal investigation into the cause of death. In India, inquests are generally conducted under BNSS (formerly CrPC). Two types of inquests exist:

 

  1. Police Inquest (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC):
    • Conducted by the police officer (minimum rank: Head Constable).
    • Most commonly used in cases of unnatural death (e.g., accidents, suicides, homicides).
  2. Magistrate Inquest (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC):
    • Conducted by an Executive or Judicial Magistrate.
    • Mandatory in special cases such as:
      • Dowry Deaths
      • Custodial Deaths
      • Exhumation (digging out a buried body)
      • However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g.  family requests a magistrate-led inquest), the magistrate can do additional inquest 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death in police custody: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC).

  • Police cannot conduct an inquest in custodial deaths

    ​

Option C. Dowry death: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC).
  • Dowry deaths must be investigated by a Magistrate, not the police

 

Option D. Death by firing: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Police inquest is done (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC).
  • A Magistrate inquest is not mandatory in cases of death by firing​

     

Educational Objective:

 

If the family is not satisfied with a police inquest, they can appeal for a Magistrate inquest, which will be preferred to ensure justice. However, custodial deaths and dowry deaths require mandatory Magistrate inquests, while deaths by firing are handled by police inquests​

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is being screened for malnutrition at a health center. According to WHO criteria, what mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) measurement indicates severe acute malnutrition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) < 11.5 cm

 

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) less than 11.5 cm is diagnostic of severe acute malnutrition (SAM). This measurement is taken using a Shakir tape, which is color-coded for easy identification by health workers:

 

  • Red zone (< 11.5 cm): Severe malnutrition
  • Yellow zone (11.5-12.5 cm): Moderate malnutrition
  • Green zone (> 12.5 cm): Normal nutritional status

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. < 12.5 cm: Incorrect. MUAC < 12.5 cm but > 11.5 cm indicates moderate acute malnutrition, not severe.

 

Option C. > 12.5 cm: Incorrect. This indicates normal nutritional status.

 

Option D. > 13.5 cm: Incorrect. This also indicates normal nutritional status. This value is not used as a cutoff in standard MUAC measurements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 cm is one of the diagnostic criteria for severe acute malnutrition in children.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true for hemolytic anemia ? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Indirect van den bergh test positive
  2. Direct van den bergh test positive
  3. Increased urine urobilonogen
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a and c


In hemolytic anemia, there is increased breakdown of red blood cells, which leads to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood. The indirect Vandenbergh test detects unconjugated bilirubin, which is increased in hemolytic anemia. Additionally, the increased breakdown of hemoglobin leads to greater production of urobilinogen, which is then excreted in urine in higher amounts. Therefore, both indirect Vandenbergh test positivity and increased urinary urobilinogen are characteristic findings in hemolytic anemia.



Direct Van den Bergh Test


Conjugated Bilirubin + Ehrlich’s Diazo Reagent → Reddish purple Azo compound(Gives colour immediately)

 

Indirect Van den Bergh Test (Doesn’t give colour immediately)
Unconjugated Bilirubin → Extraction with Alcohol → Gives colour (Water Insoluble)

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hemolytic anemia is characterized by a positive indirect Vandenbergh test (due to increased unconjugated bilirubin) and increased urine urobilinogen (due to increased hemoglobin breakdown).

questions.text: Contact dermatitis known as the ‘Scourge of India’ is caused by: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parthenium.

 

  • Parthenium hysterophorus (also known as congress grass or communist plant) is the causative agent for airborne contact dermatitis that has been referred to as the 'Scourge of India'. 

 

 

Scourge = A thing that causes great trouble or suffering

 

  • This plant releases sesquiterpene lactone (SQL) allergens into the air which settle onto exposed skin parts causing characteristic dermatitis patterns typically affecting the neck, upper eyelids, face, and V-areas of the chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Detergents - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Detergents are common causes of irritant contact dermatitis rather than allergic contact dermatitis. 
  • They cause direct tissue damage through non-immunologic mechanisms and are not specifically associated with being called the 'Scourge of India'.

 

Option C. Nickel - This is incorrect. 

 

  • While nickel is the common cause of allergic contact dermatitis worldwide, it typically causes localized reactions at sites of direct contact with metal objects (like jewelry) 

 

Option D. Ragweed - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Ragweed is a common cause of respiratory allergies and allergic rhinitis but is not specifically identified as a major cause of contact dermatitis in India. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Parthenium hysterophorus causes airborne contact dermatitis predominantly affecting exposed areas like face and neck, and due to its widespread presence and significant impact on the population, it has earned the title 'Scourge of India'.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features can be encountered in Korsakoff psychosis? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amnesia
  2. Confabulation
  3. Ophthalmoplegia
  4. Peripheral neuropathy
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 4

 

Korsakoff psychosis, or Korsakoff syndrome, is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome resulting from chronic deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1), commonly associated with chronic alcoholism. It is often considered an irreversible condition, unlike its acute counterpart, Wernicke's encephalopathy, which can be treated with thiamine supplementation.

 

Clinical Features of Korsakoff Psychosis:

 

1. Amnesia: Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by severe memory impairment, both anterograde (inability to form new memories) and retrograde (loss of previously formed memories) amnesia. Long-term memory, however, tends to remain relatively intact.

 

2. Confabulation: Patients often exhibit confabulation, where they fabricate stories to fill gaps in their memory. This is not intentional lying but a way to compensate for memory loss.

 

4. Peripheral Neuropathy: Chronic alcoholics often suffer from peripheral neuropathy due to thiamine deficiency and direct neurotoxic effects of alcohol. This neuropathy involves the axons of peripheral nerves and manifests as numbness, tingling, and pain in the extremities.

 

Other Option:

 

Not a Feature of Korsakoff Psychosis:

 

3. Ophthalmoplegia: This is a feature of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which presents acutely with a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. Ophthalmoplegia refers to paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles. It is reversible with thiamine treatment and is not typically seen in the chronic phase of Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff psychosis is characterized by severe memory impairment (amnesia), confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not include ophthalmoplegia, which is a feature of the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones reduces food intake via dual pathways by stimulating melanocyte stimulating hormone and inhibiting AgRP? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Leptin 

 

Explanation: 

 

Leptin is produced by adipose tissue and signals the status of fat stores in the body. As adipocytes increase in size, they release greater quantities of leptin which decreases food intake by increasing the expression of anorexigenic factors in the hypothalamus such as pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC). POMC is the precursor to melanocyte stimulating hormone. Leptin crosses the blood-brain barrier and activates central factors in the hypothalamus that decrease food intake through multiple pathways, including stimulating POMC/melanocyte stimulating hormone while inhibiting orexigenic factors like AgRP.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. GLP-1: While GLP-1 is a hormone released coincident with meals that plays roles in digestion and absorption, it doesn't have the specific dual effect on melanocyte stimulating hormone and AgRP described in the question.
  • Option C. Ghrelin: Contrary to the question, ghrelin is a predominantly fast-acting orexin that stimulates food intake. It increases synthesis/release of central orexins, including neuropeptide Y and cannabinoids, and suppresses the ability of leptin to stimulate anorexigenic factors.
  • Option D. Insulin: Insulin doesn't have the specific documented effect on melanocyte stimulating hormone and AgRP pathways related to food intake as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptin functions as a critical anorexigenic hormone (decreases appetite) by acting on hypothalamic centers through multiple pathways, serving as a key signal from adipose tissue to the brain about the body's energy stores.

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose water. He develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

  • Deficiency of GALT is the primary cause of classic galactosemia, which results in the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the body and leads to the symptoms described.

 

Classical Galactosemia:

 

  • It is an autosomal recessive in born error of metabolism due to deficiency of enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

 

 

  • Due to the block in this enzyme, galactose-1- phosphate will accumulate in liver. This will inhibit galactokinase as well as glycogen phosphorylase. Hypoglycemia is the result.
  • Bilirubin uptake is less and bilirubin conjugation is reduced; so unconjugated bilirubin level is increased in blood.
  • There is enlargement of liver, jaundice and severe mental retardation.
  • Free galactose accumulates, leading to galactosemia. It is partly excreted in urine (galactosuria).
  • Galactose is reduced to dulcitol. The accumulation of dulcitol in the lens results in cataract due to its osmotic effect. This is called congenital cataract and is a very characteristic feature of galactosemia.
  • Galactose-1-phosphate may get deposited in renal tubules, producing tubular damage leading to generalized amino aciduria.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical manifestation including congenital cataract and presence of galactose in urine (positive benedicts test) as well as elevated blood galactose levels will help in the diagnosis.
    • Collection of fetal cells by amniocentesis may be useful in prenatal diagnosis. Heterozygous parents could be detected by elevated galactose level in blood after a galactose load.
  • Treatment: 
    • If lactose is withdrawn from the diet, most of the symptoms recede. But mental retardation, when established, will not improve. Hence early detection is most important. For affected infant lactose-free diet is given. Such special diets may be withdrawn after 4 years, when galactose-1-phosphate pyro phosphorylase becomes active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase is not directly related to galactose metabolism and is not the cause of galactosemia.

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type II Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose and galactitol in the blood and tissues. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Option D. UDP galactose-4-epimerase: UDP galactose-4-epimerase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type III Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose-1-phosphate and UDP-galactose. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency, or classic galactosemia, is a severe metabolic disorder marked by an inability to metabolize galactose properly, leading to serious systemic symptoms including jaundice, hypoglycemia, and liver dysfunction. Early diagnosis and management through dietary adjustments are crucial for preventing long-term complications.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with an arrow: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

 

The given image represents a cross-sectional view of the thorax, and the structure marked by the arrow is identified as the pulmonary trunk. The key points to identify the pulmonary trunk are its location and the surrounding structures in the thoracic cross-section.

 

  • Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel that arises from the right ventricle of the heart and bifurcates into the right and left pulmonary arteries. It is situated anterior to the aorta and is clearly visible in the image as a large tube dividing into two branches.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carina: The carina is the point at which the trachea bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. It is located lower in the thoracic cavity and is not associated with the structures visible in the image.

 

Option B. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is located to the right of the sternum and is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option D. Arch of Aorta: The arch of the aorta is the curved portion of the aorta that gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. In a cross-sectional view, it appears as an elongated structure, not as the large round structure marked by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

choices.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
Perform more small incision cataract surgery
To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is NOT an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

 

Explanation:

 

To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots is not advisable, suggests conducting surgeries in temporary setups or less equipped facilities, typically in rural areas. This is considered unsafe and against the guidelines because such environments cannot guarantee the sterility and safety standards required for surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital: This refers to the standard protocol where patients identified as needing cataract surgery are instructed to come to a base or main hospital that is equipped for such procedures. This ensures that surgeries are performed in a controlled, sterile environment with appropriate medical facilities and staff.

 

Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS): This statement encourages the adoption of small incision cataract surgery, which is a modern technique that allows for quicker recovery times and potentially fewer complications than traditional methods. It is particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings because it does not require expensive machinery like phacoemulsification units.

 

Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area: This approach involves transporting patients from rural and remote areas to fixed, well-equipped surgical facilities, typically located in urban or suburban centers. This ensures all patients receive high-quality care in facilities that meet national and international health and safety standards.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The primary aim of these guidelines is to ensure that all surgeries, particularly sensitive ones like cataract surgery, are performed in environments that uphold the highest standards of medical care and patient safety. The emphasis is on using modern surgical techniques and ensuring that all procedures are carried out in well-equipped, permanent medical facilities to minimize risks and enhance recovery outcomes. The standard guideline includes:

 

  1. Village Register (Linelisting of cases)
  2. Screening camps
  3. Transport of cases to Base hospital
  4. Free surgery – fixed facility surgery approach (Reach in approach at base Hospitals preferred over Reach out approach as camp mode)
  5. Follow up of cases (for this camp mode is preferred)

choices.text: This infant is achieving desired target oxygen saturation.
Supplemental oxygen should be given at 100% concentration.

questions.text: A term infant has a preductal oxygen saturation of 85%, 5 minutes after birth. Which of the following is true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. This infant is achieving desired target oxygen saturation. 

 

Explanation: 

 

Normal oxygen saturation in newborns follows a predictable pattern after birth as the transition from fetal to neonatal circulation occurs. According to neonatal resuscitation guidelines, the preductal oxygen saturation (measured at right hand) at 5 minutes of life should be between 80-85%. The target ranges progress from 60-65% at 1 minute, 65-70% at 2 minutes, 70-75% at 3 minutes, 75-80% at 4 minutes, 80-85% at 5 minutes, and 85-95% at 10 minutes. Therefore, a preductal oxygen saturation of 85% at 5 minutes is within the normal range for a newborn and does not require intervention.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Oxygen supplementation is necessary - Incorrect. Supplemental oxygen is not needed when SpO2 is within normal range for age in minutes. Unnecessary oxygen can cause hyperoxemia and oxidative stress.

 

Option B. Cyanotic heart disease is suspected - Incorrect. This oxygen level is normal for a 5-minute-old infant, not suggestive of congenital heart disease. PaO2 <100mmHg despite 100% oxygen for 10-15 minutes - hyperoxia test fail suggesting cyanotic heart disease is likely.

 

Option D. Supplemental oxygen should be given at 100% concentration - Incorrect. Not only is supplemental oxygen unnecessary at this saturation, but 100% oxygen is no longer recommended in neonatal resuscitation except in specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal oxygen saturation in newborns rises gradually after birth, with 80-85% being the normal target range at 5 minutes of life. Understanding these normal transitional physiology values prevents unnecessary oxygen administration.

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described (resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

In Parkinson's disease, the brain biopsy is likely to show Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of aggregates of alpha-synuclein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirano bodies: Seen in Alzheimer's disease and other conditions like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

 

Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion) Found in cells infected with poxvirus.

 

Option D. Negri bodies: Seen in the neurons of patients with rabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Parkinson's disease, brain biopsies typically reveal Lewy bodies, which are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of alpha-synuclein.

questions.text: In Horner syndrome, ptosis is seen. In this condition, which muscle is implicated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muller's muscle

 

 

Horner syndrome is a condition resulting from a lesion in the sympathetic pathway. It is characterized by a classical triad of symptoms:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) - Mild

 

Miosis (constricted pupil)

 

Anhidrosis (lack of sweating on the affected side of the face).

 

In this condition, ptosis occurs due to the involvement of the Muller's muscle, which is a small muscle in the upper eyelid that is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system. The Muller's muscle is responsible for approximately 2 mm of eyelid elevation. When this muscle is affected, it leads to mild ptosis, which is a hallmark sign of Horner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LPS muscle: The Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS) muscle is responsible for the major elevation of the upper eyelid and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), not the sympathetic system. It is not implicated in Horner syndrome.

 

Option B. Orbicularis Oculi: This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelids and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). It plays no role in eyelid elevation and is not involved in Horner syndrome.

 

Option D. Horner muscle: There is no muscle known as the "Horner muscle." This is not a correct anatomical term and does not pertain to Horner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mild ptosis seen in Horner syndrome is due to the involvement of the Muller's muscle, which has sympathetic innervation and contributes to a small degree of eyelid elevation.

questions.text: Where are the Fissures of Santorini located? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d. External auditory meatus

 

Explanation:

 

The Fissures of Santorini are located in the external auditory meatus, specifically in the cartilaginous part of the external acoustic meatus. The cartilaginous part is C-shaped in section, and the gap of the 'C' is filled with fibrous tissue. These fissures or deficiencies in the cartilaginous wall are naturally occurring gaps that allow for flexibility of the external auditory canal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stomach - The stomach doesn't contain Fissures of Santorini. The stomach has rugae (folds) in its mucosa and has several anatomical parts including the cardia, fundus, body, and pylorus, but no structures called Fissures of Santorini.

 

Option B. Rectum - The rectum has transverse folds called rectal valves (of Houston), but not Fissures of Santorini. These valves support the weight of fecal matter and help prevent incontinence.

 

Option C. Thyroid gland - The thyroid gland consists of two lobes connected by an isthmus, with a pyramidal lobe sometimes present, but doesn't contain structures called Fissures of Santorini. You might be confusing this with the thyroglossal duct, which is an embryological structure.

 

Education Objective:

 

Fissures of Santorini are gaps in the cartilaginous wall of the external auditory meatus that provide flexibility to the ear canal and are clinically relevant as potential pathways for infection spread from the external ear to surrounding tissues.

questions.text: A child was intubated, and during auscultation, breath sounds were heard on the right side, but absent on the left side. What could be the most likely cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endobronchial intubation

 

Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is advanced too far and enters one of the main bronchi. In this case:

 

  • The ETT has likely entered the right main bronchus as the right bronchus is anatomically straighter, shorter, and more in line with the trachea
  • This results in ventilation of only one lung while the other lung collapses
  • Clinical signs include unilateral breath sounds
  • Can be confirmed by chest X-ray showing a hyperinflated ventilated lung and a collapsed contralateral lung

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheal intubation: Incorrect because normal tracheal intubation would result in bilateral breath sounds

 

Option C. Esophageal intubation: Incorrect because in esophageal intubation, there would be no breath sounds on either side and would have additional signs like gastric insufflation

 

Option D. Pneumothorax: Incorrect because pneumothorax would show absent breath sounds on the affected side with air in the pleural cavity alongwith severe hemodynamic changes, not due to selective bronchial intubation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endobronchial intubation occurs when the ETT is advanced too far into one bronchus, leading to ventilation of only one lung and collapse of the other. Proper technique, including auscultation and chest X-ray confirmation, is necessary to ensure correct ETT placement.

 

X RAY OF Endobronchial intubation

questions.text: FISH is used to detect all of the following except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point mutation

 

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is a cytogenetic technique that allows for the detection of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It is particularly useful in identifying chromosomal abnormalities such as translocations, amplifications, deletions, and aneuploidies (such as trisomy or monosomy). These alterations are detectable because they involve large-scale changes in the chromosomal structure or number that can be visualized using fluorescent probes.

 

However, FISH is not suitable for detecting point mutations. Point mutations are changes at the single nucleotide level, which are too small to be detected by this method. Point mutations require techniques that can analyze DNA sequences at a higher resolution, such as PCR-based methods, sequencing, or allele-specific oligonucleotide hybridization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translocation: FISH can detect translocations, which involve the rearrangement of chromosome segments between nonhomologous chromosomes. This can be visualized by the hybridization pattern of fluorescent probes.

 

Option B. Amplification: FISH is effective in detecting gene amplification, where multiple copies of a particular region of the chromosome are present, resulting in an intense signal from the corresponding fluorescent probe.

 

Option C. Deletion: FISH can identify deletions, including microdeletions, by showing the absence of a fluorescent signal where the DNA sequence is missing from the chromosome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is a cytogenetic technique used to detect chromosomal-level changes such as translocations, amplifications, and deletions but is not capable of detecting point mutations at the nucleotide level

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with chest pain and an ECG was taken. What will be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior MI

 

The ECG shows ST elevations primarily in leads V1, V2, V3, and V4. These elevations are also seen to some extent in V5 and aVL, with reciprocal ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. These findings are characteristic of an anterior myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior MI: This would present with ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. These changes are not observed in the provided ECG.

 

Option C. Lateral MI: This type of MI would show ST elevations primarily in leads I, aVL, and possibly V5 and V6, but not in leads V1 to V4.

 

Option D. Posterior MI: The diagnosis of a posterior MI is typically confirmed by obtaining posterior leads (V7, V8, and V9) to demonstrate ST elevations. Alternatively, it can be inferred from characteristic ST depressions in leads V1 and V2, often with a tall R wave and upright T wave, which are not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior MI is characterized by ST elevations in leads V1 to V4, with possible involvement of V5 and AVL, and reciprocal ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF.

questions.text: What compound is responsible for the "coral-red" fluorescence observed under Wood's lamp examination in cases of Erythrasma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coproporphyrin III

 

  • Erythrasma, caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, shows a characteristic coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination due to the production of Coproporphyrin III by the bacteria. 

 

 

  • This fluorescence is a diagnostic feature of erythrasma and helps differentiate it from other similar-appearing conditions. 
  • When Wood's lamp (ultraviolet light at 365 nm wavelength) is shined on erythrasma lesions, the porphyrin compound emits this distinctive fluorescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminolevulonic acid (ALA) - This is incorrect. 

  • ALA is a precursor in the porphyrin synthesis pathway but is not directly responsible for the coral-red fluorescence in erythrasma. 
  • ALA is used in photodynamic therapy where it's metabolized to protoporphyrin IX, which fluoresces red under certain conditions.

 

Option C. Protoporphyrin IX - This is incorrect. 

  • Protoporphyrin IX is a porphyrin compound that can fluoresce red, but it's not the specific compound responsible for the coral-red fluorescence in erythrasma. 
  • Protoporphyrin IX accumulates in certain porphyrias and is used in photodynamic diagnosis.

 

Option D. Uroporphyrin I - This is incorrect. 

  • Uroporphyrin I is another porphyrin compound that can fluoresce, but it's not the specific compound that causes the coral-red fluorescence in erythrasma. 
  • Uroporphyrins accumulate in certain types of porphyria, particularly porphyria cutanea tarda.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coproporphyrin III produced by Corynebacterium minutissimum is responsible for the pathognomonic coral-red fluorescence observed under Wood's lamp examination in erythrasma, making this a valuable diagnostic test for this condition.

choices.text: To improve quality of life patient
Nothing is done in palliative care

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of stage IV non-small cell lung cancer presents with worsening dyspnea, non-productive cough, and uncontrolled pain despite current medication. He has declined further aggressive treatment. What stands true for Palliative care? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To improve quality of life patient

 

Explanation:

 

  • Palliative care is a specialized medical care focused on providing relief from the symptoms and stress of a serious illness.
  • The primary goal of palliative care is to improve the quality of life for the patient. 
  • It involves treating pain and other distressing symptoms, providing psychological and spiritual care, and supporting the patient and their family to cope with the challenges of a serious illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To cure disease: This is incorrect. Palliative care does not aim to cure the underlying disease but focuses on alleviating symptoms and improving the quality of life for both the patient and their family.

 

Option B. Do nothing to prolong life: Palliative care does not necessarily aim to prolong life, nor does it hasten death. It’s about enhancing the quality of life and may also indirectly prolong it by improving general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Nothing is done in palliative care: This is incorrect. Palliative care involves active and comprehensive management of various issues that arise with serious illnesses, including physical, emotional, social, and spiritual aspects of care.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Palliative care is crucial for improving the quality of life for patients with serious illnesses. 
  • It addresses a wide range of needs, ensuring the patient’s comfort and supporting the family through difficult times, emphasizing symptom management and personal support over curative treatments.

questions.text: Reliable feature of some dehydration is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Thirst

 

Thirst is recognized as the most reliable feature of some dehydration. When dehydration begins to set in, the body's initial response is to signal thirst as a way to encourage fluid intake. This response is consistent across various cases of mild to moderate dehydration. Unlike other symptoms, thirst is a direct and early indicator of dehydration that can be easily recognized by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: Skin turgor, or the delayed return of the skin to its normal position after being pinched, is influenced by several factors, including nutritional status. This makes it less reliable as a sole indicator of dehydration.

 

Option B. Lethargy: Lethargy can be a symptom of dehydration, but it is difficult to quantify and may vary widely depending on the individual's overall health and the severity of dehydration.

 

Option D. Sunken eyes: The appearance of sunken eyes is quite subjective and often requires the input of a caregiver, such as a parent, to determine whether it is present. It is also not always a definitive sign of dehydration, making it less reliable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thirst is the most reliable and early feature of some dehydration, making it a critical symptom to recognize in assessing dehydration

questions.text: A patient presented with 2 Lisch nodules in the iris. What is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are pigmented, benign hamartomas found in the iris of the eye. They are highly specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), also known as von Recklinghausen disease. NF1 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors called neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and other neurological and ocular manifestations.

 

Key diagnostic feature:

 

  • Lisch nodules: These are melanocytic hamartomas and are considered a hallmark of NF1. Their presence, particularly when there are two or more, is diagnostic of NF1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This genetic disorder is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, kidneys, and heart. It is associated with other ocular findings such as retinal hamartomas, but not with Lisch nodules.

 

Option C. Sturge-Weber syndrome: This congenital disorder is associated with a port-wine stain birthmark, neurological abnormalities, and ocular issues like glaucoma, but not with Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Von Hippel Lindau syndrome: This is a genetic disorder that leads to the formation of tumors and cysts in different parts of the body, particularly the kidneys, pancreas, and central nervous system. It is not associated with Lisch nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lisch nodules in the iris is highly specific for Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), making it a key diagnostic feature for this condition

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

 

 

HS-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis.

 

Other investigations that can help include:

 

  • CSF examination
  • CSF culture
  • Serological studies
  • MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

 

The image shows coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM antibodies in CSF: Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear of CSF: Rapid, fairly sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method, but prepared from the lesions, preferably from the base of vesicles and stained with 1% aqueous solution of toluidine blue ‘0’ for 15 seconds, not CSF.

 

Option D. CSF culture in chick embryos: HSV-1 doesn’t grow well on Chick embryo line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text: A child presents with intellectual disability, short stature, hypotonia, obesity, small hands and feet, and hypogonadism. He has been diagnosed with Prader-Willi syndrome. Which of the following chromosomes is affected in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromosome 15

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by abnormalities on chromosome 15.

 

This occurs due to one of three mechanisms:

 

  • Deletion of the paternal chromosome 15 (most common, about 70% of cases)
  • Maternal uniparental disomy (both copies of chromosome 15 come from the mother)
  • Imprinting defect.

 

Prader willi syndrome

 

Etiology

 

  • Deletion of paternal chromosome (MC cause)
  • Uniparental Disomy (maternal chromosome)
  • ↓↓ SNORP (Small nucleolar RNA Proteins)

 

Clinical features

 

  • Mental Retardation
  • Obesity
  • Hypotonia
  • Hypogonadism

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromosome 11: Incorrect. Chromosome 11 abnormalities are associated with other conditions like Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and Wilms tumor, not Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option B. Chromosome 12: Incorrect. Chromosome 12 is not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome. Abnormalities of this chromosome may be linked to other conditions.

 

Option D. Chromosome 17: Incorrect. Chromosome 17 is associated with conditions like Miller-Dieker syndrome and Smith-Magenis syndrome, not Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by abnormalities on chromosome 15, specifically the absence of paternally expressed genes in the 15q11-q13 region.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Allergic rhinitis is a condition characterized by symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose, and itchy eyes. These symptoms can lead to several physical signs due to chronic inflammation and repetitive actions like rubbing the nose and eyes. However we do not see Otto Veraguth folds in Allergic Rhinitis.

 Also known as Veraguth folds, these are small creases on the upper eyelid and are not related to allergic rhinitis. They are typically associated with individuals suffering from depression, not allergic conditions.

Other Options:

Option A. Allergic Shiners: Commonly seen in allergic rhinitis due to venous congestion under the eyes.

Option B. Allergic Salute: A habitual action in allergic rhinitis leading to a nasal crease.

Option D. Dennis Morgan Lines: Found in chronic allergic conditions due to persistent inflammation and edema, including allergic rhinitis.

Educational Objective: 

Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: Glucocorticoids decrease the number of circulating: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Eosinophils

 

Explanation: 

 

Glucocorticoids cause a significant decrease in the number of circulating eosinophils by increasing their sequestration in the spleen and lungs. This effect is a fundamental immunological action of glucocorticoids, with eosinophil counts typically dropping from around 275 to 50 cells/μL with cortisol treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Neutrophils - This is incorrect because glucocorticoids actually increase the number of neutrophils in circulation. Neutrophil counts typically rise from approximately 4,000 to 10,000 cells/μL with cortisol treatment.
  • Option C. Platelets - This is incorrect as glucocorticoids increase rather than decrease platelet counts. Glucocorticoids lower the number of basophils in the circulation while increasing the number of neutrophils, platelets, and red blood cells.
  • Option D. Red Blood Cells - This is incorrect because glucocorticoids increase the number of red blood cells in circulation, not decrease them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Glucocorticoids have diverse effects on blood cell populations, causing a reduction in eosinophils, basophils, and lymphocytes while increasing neutrophils, platelets, and red blood cells through mechanisms involving altered cellular distribution and production.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest pH? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pancreatic juice

 

Explanation: 

 

Pancreatic juice has a pH of 8-8.3, making it the most alkaline (highest pH) among the given options. Pancreatic juice contains high concentrations of bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻), which is secreted in response to secretin. In fact, the maximum HCO₃⁻ secretion in the GI tract occurs in the pancreas, contributing to its high alkalinity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Gastric juice - Has a pH of 1.2-3, making it highly acidic due to the secretion of HCl by parietal cells. This is the most acidic secretion in the GI tract.
  • Option B. Bile - While bile is alkaline in nature and contains bicarbonate, its pH is not as high as pancreatic juice. Bile serves as an excretory fluid and aids in fat emulsification.
  • Option D. Saliva - Has a pH of 6-7, making it slightly acidic to neutral. While it contains some bicarbonate, it's not as alkaline as pancreatic juice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic juice has the highest pH (8-8.3) among major GI secretions due to its high bicarbonate content, which is essential for neutralizing acidic chyme from the stomach to provide the optimal pH for pancreatic enzymes to function.

questions.text: A baby who can ride a tricycle, can walk alternate steps on stairs, he cannot do hopping. What is the age of the baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3.5 years

 

A 3-year-old child can typically ride a tricycle and walk up stairs with alternate feet. The ability to ride a tricycle is usually developed around the age of 3, as "tri" refers to three, indicating this milestone. Walking up stairs with alternate feet is another skill that a 3-year-old can manage. However, hopping on one foot usually develops around the age of 4. Since the child in question cannot hop yet, it indicates the child is likely not yet 4 years old. Therefore, the best answer is 3.5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child who can ride a tricycle and walk up stairs with alternate feet but cannot hop is typically around 3.5 years old.

choices.text: All of the above are correct

questions.text: Regarding Congenital Talipes Equinovarus (CTEV), all of the following statements are true except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Varus at the talonavicular joint

 

This statement is incorrect because in CTEV (clubfoot), the varus deformity occurs primarily at the subtalar joint, not at the talonavicular joint. The subtalar joint is where the talus articulates with the calcaneum, and when the calcaneum is inverted, it takes the whole foot with it so that the sole faces medially, creating the varus deformity. The talonavicular joint contributes more to the adduction component of the deformity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This is correct. Equinus deformity in CTEV occurs primarily at the ankle joint (tibiotalar joint). The foot is fixed in plantar flexion at this joint, creating the equinus component.

 

Option C: This is correct. The adduction deformity in CTEV occurs at the midtarsal joints, mainly at the talonavicular joint. This creates the medial deviation of the forefoot, which is a key component of clubfoot.

 

Option D: This is incorrect because option B contains an error. Not all of the statements are correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In CTEV, the pathoanatomy involves specific deformities at different joints: equinus at the ankle (tibiotalar) joint, varus at the subtalar joint, and adduction at the midtarsal joints (primarily talonavicular). Understanding the precise location of each deformity component is crucial for proper treatment planning.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

 

Explanation:

 

XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.

 

Option C. Ebola: Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.

 

Option D. Congo Crimean Fever: Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is NOT associated with a substantially greater risk of developing epilepsy after febrile seizures? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Family history of Febrile Seizure

 

Family history of febrile seizures is primarily associated with recurrence of febrile seizures rather than development of epilepsy. While it increases the likelihood of having another febrile seizure, it doesn't substantially raise the risk of developing epilepsy. The risk factors table shows that epilepsy risk is 1% after simple febrile seizures, 6% after complex febrile seizures, and much higher (29-33%) with neurodevelopmental abnormalities or family history of epilepsy (18%).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complex Febrile seizures - Complex febrile seizures increase the risk of developing epilepsy to approximately 6%, which is six times higher than with simple febrile seizures.

 

Option C. Developmental Delay - Neurodevelopmental abnormality carries a 33% risk of subsequent epilepsy development, making it one of the strongest risk factors.

 

Option D. Epilepsy in first-degree relatives - Family history of epilepsy increases the risk to approximately 18%, which is significantly higher than the baseline risk.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While family history of febrile seizures increases the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures, it does not substantially increase the risk of developing epilepsy, unlike neurodevelopmental abnormalities, complex febrile seizures, or family history of epilepsy.

questions.text: A fracture that involves the epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis is classified as which type of Salter-Harris fracture? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Type IV

 

Salter-Harris Type IV fracture involves a vertical fracture line that extends from the articular surface through the epiphysis, across the growth plate (physis), and into the metaphysis. This is a complete fracture that traverses all three components - epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis. These fractures require precise anatomical reduction, usually through open reduction and internal fixation, as they have a high risk of growth disturbance if not properly aligned.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: This fracture involves only the growth plate (physis) with complete separation of the epiphysis from the metaphysis. The fracture line runs horizontally through the physis without involving either the epiphysis or metaphysis.

 

Option B. Type II: This fracture extends through the physis and partially into the metaphysis (creating the Thurston-Holland fragment), but does not involve the epiphysis. The epiphyseal surface remains intact.

 

Option C. Type III: This fracture extends vertically through the epiphysis and physis but stops at the metaphysis. It involves the articular surface but does not extend into the metaphysis, differentiating it from Type IV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salter-Harris Type IV fractures are the only type that involve all three anatomical components (epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis) and therefore have a high risk of growth disturbance, requiring accurate reduction to prevent long-term complications.

questions.text: Which medication is considered the drug of choice for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Sodium Valproate

 

Explanation:

 

Benign Rolandic Epilepsy, also known as Benign Childhood Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), is one of the most common childhood epilepsy syndromes. Sodium valproate is considered the drug of choice for this condition due to its broad spectrum antiepileptic properties and effectiveness in controlling both partial and generalized seizures. It works by increasing brain levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), an inhibitory neurotransmitter.

 

Benign Rolandic Epilepsy typically presents with focal seizures involving the face, particularly during sleep, and has a characteristic EEG pattern with centrotemporal spikes. The condition is self-limiting and generally resolves by adolescence, but antiepileptic therapy may be needed during the active phase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gabapentin - Incorrect. While gabapentin is used as an anticonvulsant, it is not the first-line therapy for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy. It is more commonly used for neuropathic pain and as adjunctive therapy for partial seizures.

 

Option C. Barbiturates - Incorrect. Barbiturates are older generation antiepileptic drugs with significant side effects including sedation and cognitive impairment. They are rarely used as first-line therapy for childhood epilepsies today.

 

Option D. Phenytoin - Incorrect. Phenytoin is primarily effective against generalized tonic-clonic and partial seizures but is not the drug of choice for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy due to its side effect profile and pharmacokinetic variability in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium valproate is the preferred first-line treatment for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy due to its efficacy and relatively favorable side effect profile compared to other antiepileptic medications in children.

questions.text: DNA repair gene defect with increased risk of skin cancer is a feature of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xeroderma pigmentosum

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) gene. This defect impairs the body's ability to repair DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) light, leading to a significantly increased risk of developing skin cancers, including basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma, even at a young age.

 

Patients with xeroderma pigmentosum often exhibit extreme sensitivity to sunlight, with symptoms such as severe sunburn, freckling, and pigmentation changes. Over time, the accumulation of unrepaired DNA damage increases the likelihood of malignant transformations in skin cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bloom syndrome: Bloom syndrome is also associated with increased cancer risk, but it does not specifically present with a high risk of skin cancers due to UV sensitivity. It involves a different DNA repair pathway (homologous recombination repair) and is characterized by short stature, sun-sensitive skin changes, and a predisposition to various cancers.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: Ataxia telangiectasia is a condition caused by mutations in the ATM gene, affecting the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. While it increases the risk of leukemia and lymphoma, it is not primarily associated with an increased risk of skin cancers due to UV sensitivity.

 

Option D. Lynch syndrome: Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) involves mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes and is associated with an increased risk of colorectal, endometrial, and other cancers, but not specifically skin cancers or UV-related cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is characterized by a defect in the Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER) gene, leading to increased sensitivity to UV light and a significantly elevated risk of developing skin cancers.

questions.text: Two friends were working together at a construction site. A hammer fell from one friend's hand and hit the other friend’s head. The X-ray revealed a fracture. What type of fracture is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Depressed Fracture

 

Explanation:

 

A depressed fracture occurs when a heavy object with a small surface area (such as a hammer) strikes the skull, causing the bone to get pushed inward.

 

Characteristics of a Depressed Fracture:

 

  • Caused by blunt force trauma with a small, focused impact area (e.g., hammer, stone, rod).
  • Bone fragments get displaced inwards, compressing brain tissue.
  • Visible on X-ray or CT scan as a concave depression in the skull bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Linear Fracture: Incorrect

 

  • Appears as a thin line without bone displacement.
  • Caused by broad-surface impact (e.g., falls, RTA).

  • Most common type of skull fracture but not caused by a hammer

     

Option C. Gutter Fracture:  Incorrect

 

  • Occurs when a bullet or projectile grazes the skull, forming a trough-like depression.

  • Not caused by a falling hammer

    ​

Option D. Ping Pong Fracture: Incorrect

 

  • Seen in infants due to the soft, elastic nature of their skulls.
  • Skull buckles inward without breaking (resembles a ping pong ball dent).

  • Not seen in adults or due to a hammer injury

    ​

Educational Objective:

 

Types of Skull Fractures

questions.text: Constituents of nasal septum include all except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perpendicular plate of palatine

 

Explanation: 

 

The nasal septum is composed of both bony and cartilaginous components. The main constituents include the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone superiorly, the vomer posteroinferiorly, the quadrangular cartilage anteriorly, and the maxillary crest inferiorly. The perpendicular plate of the palatine bone is not a constituent of the nasal septum.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vomer: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The vomer is a thin, flat bone that forms the posteroinferior portion of the nasal septum. It articulates with the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid superiorly and the maxillary crest inferiorly.

 

Option C. Quadrangular cartilage: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The quadrangular cartilage (septal cartilage) forms the major anterior portion of the nasal septum. It is attached to the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid posterosuperiorly and to the vomer posteroinferiorly.

 

Option D. Maxillary crest: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The maxillary crest forms a ridge along the nasal floor that supports the inferior edge of the nasal septum. It is formed by the fusion of the palatine processes of the maxillae.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The nasal septum consists of the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone, vomer, quadrangular cartilage, and maxillary crest, but does not include the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cytochrome C oxidase inhibitor? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nitric oxide


Nitric oxide is not an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV of electron transport chain). NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme NO synthase and causes vasodilation. It has a role in physiological processes like erection and is inhibited by smoking, which can lead to erectile dysfunction.

 

Inhibitors of ETC Complexes

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Carbon monoxide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Carbon monoxide is part of the mnemonic "i'd" which includes carbon monoxide, cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, and sodium azide as inhibitors of complex IV.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulfide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Hydrogen sulfide is listed among the substances that inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.

 

Option D. Cyanide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Cyanide is included in the list of substances that inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:


Nitric oxide (NO) is not an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV), while carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulfide, and cyanide are inhibitors of this complex IV  in the electron transport chain.

questions.text: A case of trauma presents to the Emergency with an unknown blood group. Since the patient was hemodynamically unstable, he required immediate blood transfusion. Which blood type can be transfused? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) O positive and O negative

 

In emergency situations where the patient's blood group is unknown, and immediate blood transfusion is required, O negative blood is preferred because it is known as the universal donor. O negative blood can be transfused to any patient regardless of their blood type since it lacks A, B, and Rh antigens, minimizing the risk of adverse reactions.

 

However, if O negative blood is not available, O positive blood can be used, especially in life-threatening situations. While O positive is not universally compatible like O negative, it is still relatively safe for transfusion in emergencies, particularly in patients who are male or non-childbearing females, where the risks of Rh incompatibility are lower.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive and O negative: A positive blood can only be given to A positive or AB positive recipients. It is not suitable for unknown blood types in emergencies.

 

Option B. AB negative and O negative: AB negative blood is not a universal donor; it can only be given to AB negative recipients.

 

Option D. A positive and O positive: Similar to option A, A positive is not universally compatible and is therefore not ideal in emergency situations where the blood type is unknown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Universal blood donor and the safest option: O negative.

questions.text: Siffert-Katz sign is seen in? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blount’s disease

 

Siffert-Katz sign refers to a palpable posteromedial depression of the proximal tibial metaphysis and epiphysis, which can be associated with varus instability of the knee in early flexion (around 15-20 degrees). This sign indicates an intra-articular deformity characteristic of Blount's disease. 

 

The abnormal growth at the medial tibial growth plate in Blount's disease leads to this characteristic bony depression. When the knee is flexed to around 15-20 degrees, this depression can become more prominent and may be associated with varus instability (a tendency for the knee to buckle inwards).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perthes Disease is a condition affecting the hip joint in children, typically between the ages of 4 and 10. It involves a temporary disruption of blood supply to the femoral head, causing it to lose bone mass and potentially deform. The pathological changes occur in the femoral head and acetabulum, leading to symptoms like limping, hip pain, and restricted hip movement. There is no involvement of the proximal tibia or the specific posteromedial depression seen in Blount's disease. 

 

Option C: Osteogenesis Imperfecta presents with multiple fractures at various stages of healing due to bone fragility. It has specific radiographic findings related to thin cortices and multiple fractures, not the Siffert-Katz sign.

 

Option D: Pulled elbow (Nursemaid's elbow) is a subluxation of the proximal radioulnar joint. It typically has normal radiographs as it's primarily a soft tissue injury involving the annular ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Siffert-Katz sign, the palpable posteromedial depression of the proximal tibia associated with varus instability in early knee flexion, is a specific clinical finding that helps in the diagnosis of Blount's disease, particularly the infantile form. It reflects the unique way the proximal tibial growth plate is affected in this condition.

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night blindness is a late feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a group of hereditary disorders that cause progressive degeneration of the retina, specifically affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones).

 

Night blindness is a late feature: This is incorrect. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is an early feature of RP. Patients often present with difficulties in dark adaptation and night vision long before significant peripheral vision loss occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave: Electroretinography (ERG) in RP patients shows decreased amplitude of both the a wave (originating from rods and cones) and the b wave (originating from bipolar cells).

 

Option B. Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy: RP typically starts with rod dysfunction, which later involves the cones.

 

Option C. Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision: RP usually presents with mid-peripheral vision loss, which progresses to peripheral vision loss and eventually central vision loss, leading to tunnel vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

choices.text: It acts as an alkylating agent
It inhibits polymerization of tubulin monomers in mitosis

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of cancer? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It inhibits dihydrofolate reductase

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug used in the treatment of various types of cancer. Its primary mechanism of action is the inhibition of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). DHFR is crucial for the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, which is necessary for the synthesis of purines and thymidylate, essential components of DNA. By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate leads to the depletion of tetrahydrofolate and ultimately inhibits DNA synthesis, cell replication, and cell function, which is particularly effective against rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acts as an alkylating agent: Alkylating agents work by adding an alkyl group to the DNA molecule, which can lead to DNA strand breaks and cell death. Methotrexate does not work by this mechanism.

 

Option C. Inhibits topoisomerase II: Topoisomerase II inhibitors prevent the DNA from uncoiling and duplicating. Drugs like etoposide and doxorubicin work by this mechanism.

 

Option D. Inhibits polymerization of tubulin monomers in mitosis: This is the mechanism of action of drugs like vincristine and paclitaxel, which interfere with microtubule formation and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate exerts its anticancer effects primarily by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, thereby blocking the synthesis of DNA and RNA necessary for cell replication.

questions.text: A renal biopsy of a patient is shown below. Identify the cells marked in the given histological image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macula densa

 

Explanation: 

 

"These which are marked with the green color they are nothing but inside the tubule which must be the end part of the ascending membrane group of Henle or the beginning of DCT. It is none other than macula densa cells, which act as key sensors in the nephron, sensing sodium (Na⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻) levels. Macula densa cells are columnar epithelial cells that act as chemosensors for Na+ and Cl-

 

  • They are part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA)
  • They are located in the distal tubule where it contacts the afferent arteriole
  • They play a crucial role in tubuloglomerular feedback

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JG cells: Incorrect because JG cells are modified smooth muscle cells located in the wall of the afferent arteriole.

 

Option C. Lacis cells: Incorrect because Lacis cells (also called extraglomerular mesangial cells) are located between the afferent and efferent arterioles and have a supportive function.

 

Option D. Podocytes: Incorrect because Podocytes are specialized epithelial cells that form the visceral layer of Bowman's capsule and play a role in filtration barrier formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macula densa cells are specialized columnar epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, forming part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA). They function as chemosensors, detecting sodium (Na⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻) levels and regulating tubuloglomerular feedback to maintain glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumor is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone

 

  • Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.
  • Pott puffy tumor is a soft doughy forehead swelling due to frontal bone osteomyelitis with associated subperiosteal abscess. PPT is a rare complication of frontal sinusitis, but can also occur due to trauma.
  • It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.
  • The pathophysiology for the development of frontal skull osteomyelitis can occur due to hematogenous spread of the infection or to direct extension of infection.
  • Presents with tender forehead swelling associated with fever, headaches, nasal discharge, or symptoms of increased intracranial pressure
  • Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, it requires removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap through a coronal incision

 

 

Complications of frontal sinusitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subperiosteal abscess of ethmoid bone: Incorrect, as the ethmoid bone typically presents with other orbital or intranasal complications.

 

Option C. Mucocele of frontal bone: Incorrect, as mucoceles refer to mucus-filled cysts resulting from blocked sinus ducts, not infections.

 

Option D. Mucocele of ethmoid bone: Also incorrect and refers to a different pathological condition involving the ethmoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pott's puffy tumor is a severe and rare complication of frontal sinusitis, presenting with distinctive forehead swelling and potentially grave complications. Prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment are crucial to prevent further spread of infection and ensure recovery.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 224

choices.text: Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: Cholangiocarcinoma is not a complication of?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that forms in the bile ducts. It is associated with various risk factors and conditions, but Hepatitis B is not directly linked to its development. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is primarily associated with hepatocellular carcinoma, which is a different type of liver cancer. The other options listed are known risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Opisthorchis: This parasitic infection is a known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. 

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This chronic liver disease involving inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts is a significant risk factor for developing cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Caroli's disease: This congenital disorder characterized by cystic dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts increases the risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus primarily causes hepatocellular carcinoma, not cholangiocarcinoma, unlike other liver conditions such as parasitic infections, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and Caroli's disease.

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patent with burn involving the chest and abdomen right arm and right thigh (circumferental): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31.5% 

 

According to the ‘Rule of Nine’, BSA is calculated as: 

 

  • Chest and Abdomen = 18%
  • Right Arm (not entire upper limb) = 4.5%
  • Right Thigh = 9%

 

Total = 18% + 4.5% + 9% = 31.5%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. It divides the body into sections that represent approximately 9% of the total surface area, facilitating quick and effective assessment and treatment planning for burn patients.

questions.text: A woman purchased a food item from a shopkeeper who was subsequently arrested for food adulteration. Meanwhile, the woman develops visual disturbances and cardiac failure. The underlying toxin is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sanguinarine

 

The question describes a case of food adulteration that led to symptoms such as visual disturbances (Glaucoma) and cardiac failure. These symptoms are characteristic of a condition known as epidemic dropsy, which is caused by the consumption of adulterated mustard oil. The toxic adulterant in this case is Argemone mexicana oil, which contains the toxin sanguinarine. Sanguinarine inhibits the oxidation of pyruvic acid in the blood, leading to the symptoms observed in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BOAA: This is a toxin found in Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal) and can lead to neurolathyrism, a condition characterized by neuromuscular symptoms, not by visual disturbances or cardiac failure.

 

Option C. Ergot toxin: This toxin is associated with ergotism, which causes symptoms like hallucinations, gangrene, and convulsions.

 

Option D. Aflatoxin: Aflatoxin is a mycotoxin produced by Aspergillus species, often found in improperly stored food items like grains and nuts. It is a potent carcinogen but does not cause the acute symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration diseases:

questions.text: A person missing from home is found wandering purposefully. He is well-groomed and denies having any amnesia. Most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Dissociative fugue

 

Explanation:

 

Dissociative fugue is marked by sudden, unexpected travel away from home or familiar surroundings. During a fugue, individuals often appear well-groomed and behave in a seemingly normal, goal-directed way, which reflects preserved self-care and orientation. However, once the fugue ends, they usually experience amnesia for what occurred during the episode. While in the fugue state, they might not even recognize anything is wrong and may deny memory issues. These episodes can last from minutes to months, and some individuals may have recurrent fugues. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue is considered a specifier of dissociative amnesia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Dissociative amnesia: This involves an inability to recall important personal information, usually related to trauma or stress, but it does not necessarily  include the travel or wandering behavior seen in fugue states. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue has been made a subtype of dissociative amnesia. 
  • Option C. Schizophrenia: People with schizophrenia may wander, but it’s typically disorganized or bizarre rather than purposeful. There are other signs also  like hallucinations, delusions, or negative symptoms. The person’s well-groomed appearance and coherent behavior is  against this diagnosis.
  • Option D. Dementia: Wandering can happen in dementia, but the onset is usually gradual, and the person often appears disheveled or confused. Dementia-related wandering stems from memory loss and impaired judgment, not dissociation. Plus, the sudden nature described in this case doesn't fit with how dementia typically presents.

 

Educational Objective:


If someone suddenly leaves home and ends up in a new place with intact self-care, normal-seeming behavior, and later has no memory of it, it must be dissociative fugue—especially if there are no psychotic or neurocognitive symptoms present.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary PPH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Placenta previa

 

Explanation:

 

Placenta previa is not a cause of secondary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). It is primarily associated with antepartum hemorrhage (bleeding before delivery) and is a risk factor for primary PPH (occurring within the first 24 hours after childbirth).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Retained cotyledon: Retained cotyledon can lead to secondary PPH due to retained placental fragments, causing continued uterine bleeding.

 

Option B. Endometritis: Endometritis, an infection of the uterine lining, can cause secondary PPH by leading to inflammation and impaired uterine contraction.

 

Option C. Placental polyp: A placental polyp, which is retained placental tissue that forms a growth, can cause secondary PPH through persistent bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is a cause of antepartum hemorrhage and primary postpartum hemorrhage but not secondary postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 804, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Post-partum IUCD insertion can be inserted till? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48h

 

Postpartum IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) insertion is classified into early postpartum and late postpartum insertion.

 

  • Early Postpartum IUCD (PPIUCD): This can be further divided into:
     
    • Within 10 minutes of placental delivery: This is known as immediate PPIUCD insertion.
    • After 10 minutes but within 48 hours of delivery: This is still considered early postpartum insertion and can be performed either after vaginal delivery or during a cesarean section.
       

If the IUCD is not inserted within this 48-hour window, it cannot be inserted until after six weeks postpartum. This period between 48 hours and six weeks is a contraindicated window for IUCD insertion due to the increased risk of expulsion and complications.

 

  • Late Postpartum IUCD: This insertion is done after six weeks postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postpartum IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery or after six weeks postpartum. The period between 48 hours and six weeks is contraindicated for IUCD insertion.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presented with painless right scrotal swelling for 2 months. The left testis was normal. There were enlarged para-aortic nodes. USG showed right testicular mass. What will be the management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High inguinal orchiectomy

 

Explanation: 


This is a classic presentation of testicular tumor (likely seminoma) with para-aortic lymph node metastasis. High inguinal orchiectomy is the standard initial management. The procedure involves removing the entire testis with spermatic cord through an inguinal incision. This approach is crucial because:

 

  • It allows control of lymphatic and vascular supply at the deep inguinal ring
  • Prevents tumor spillage and local spread
  • Avoids breaching the scrotum which could lead to tumor seeding
  • Helps maintain proper oncological principles

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biopsy of scrotal mass - Incorrect

 

  • Biopsy or FNAC is contraindicated in testicular tumors as it may cause tumor spillage and upstaging
  • Can lead to scrotal violation and altered lymphatic drainage

 

Option C. Scrotal orchiectomy - Incorrect

 

  • Associated with high risk of local recurrence
  • Breaches scrotal skin which can lead to tumor seeding
  • Changes the lymphatic drainage pattern
  • Can cause upstaging of the tumor

 

Option D. Biopsy of lymph node - Incorrect

 

  • Not needed at initial diagnosis
  • Primary management is always removal of the testicular mass
  • Para-aortic nodes are consistent with the natural lymphatic spread pattern
  • Further staging can be done after orchiectomy

 

Educational Objective:


High inguinal orchiectomy is the standard initial management for testicular tumors. Scrotal violation must be avoided to prevent tumor spillage and upstaging.
